Yes, most big cats also does the box thing;
there's a video by "Big Cat Rescue," titled "BIG CATS like boxes too!"
That documents several species of large cats sitting in boxes.
(Species included in the video: Lion, Jaguar, Panther, Lynx, Tiger, Caracal, Serval, + one I don't know.)

P.S.
They are in captivity, which might change the result;
however, I've seen images from other sources, that also shows big cats liking boxes.
Also, I don't think putting a cardboard box, out on the savanna, along with a camera, would be the hardest experiment to perform; cardboard mostly just being wood, hence it's biodegradable, meaning that pollution shouldn't really be a concern, for this experiment.

I've replicated the experiment utilizing a small pride of Bengal House Cats (Snow leopard lineage), and would say that with this particular breed the conclusions are a bit different. Boxes are safe, but also act as a hunting blind...ya know, just in case the mood strikes. Sleeping in your blind only makes sense for those of us that "Work smart, not hard."

Two, or B, whichever I'm doing--spots are preferable based on a scale of "Pride Rock" esthetics. The more it aligns with royalty, the high ground, and a plan coming together the more desirable it is, and sometime even worth fighting the group to attain.

Also, are we sure cats are ACTUALLY being fooled by the illusions, or just uncaring because it fits a certain criteria for them? Such as it being new and shiny? Was that tested for?

OMG, the bit about barfing in the exact spot for you step in it just cracked me up. For me it's not just the bathroom in the middle of the night, but 9 out of 10 barfs are found by one of my feet. Out of those nine, I swear 9 out of 10 of them are found by my left foot. Statistically, you'd think half of all foot-found barfs would be found by each foot, but nope.

Even worse, out of the four human feet in the house, mine seem to find the majority of the barfs. I have to wonder if the fact that mine are almost always sheathed in socks whereas my wife's are rarely sheathed in socks is a contributing factor. Does cat barf just like socks more than bare feet? I don't know, but I'm not running the experiment to find out because I'd also have to somehow get my wife to sheath her feet in socks during the experiment so I can account for the male vs female feet as another possible factor.

This reminds me of something I saw a while back that used mirrors to understand how smart an animal really was. The video was about elephants, but it mentioned that cats had failed the experiment to see if they were aware that it was a mirror image or not.

Now that you brought up how they act differently in a lab, that certainly makes a lot more sense.

I have definitely had my fair share or dumb cats, but my current one is too smart for her own good.

Using the mirror as an example, if you're in front of one and annoy her she's likely to look at you through the mirror instead of whipping her head around at an odd angle to look directly up. Or, if I shine a laser through the mirror, she automatically switches to the point on her side of the mirror, even if it isn't going the direction of the dot she was following.

There's a pair of related errors in this video that are bugging me. First, is that it's "Kanizsa", not "Kanisza", and yes, there's a difference because it's a Hungarian word. Second is that "sz" is pronounced like an "s" in Hungarian, not "ts"; "s" in Hungarian represents an "sh" sound. "zs", for the record, is pronounced like a French "j". If it were spelled as Hank's pronouncing it, it's be spelled "kanica".

Rules of cats’ intrinsic unpredictability:
Rule #1 - if you have two cats, and the first one likes to do something, the other one will like to do the opposite. Or nothing at all.
Rule #2 - cats detect immediately when you try to study them and aim at defeating any attempt at defining rules about them. In labs they do the opposite of what they do in real life. Or they do nothing at all.

I heard that cats are notoriously hard to study in lab environments because they don't care about some things. Like the thing with the mirror. Cats do recognize themselves and others in a mirror. They use mirrors to plan an attack on their fellow cats and such. But if you put a dot in their fur and sit them in front of a mirror, they absolutely do not care that there's a dot in their fur, that way making the experiment useless. And it took a long time for the scientists to figure out that they are the stupid ones in the experiments.

1:25 was named after Gaetano KANIZSA (zs pronounced like the “s” in pleasure)
Wiki says: He was born on 18 August 1913 in Trieste, Italy to a Hungarian-Jewish father from Nagybecskerek and a Slovene Catholic mother from Bovec. His surname is analogous to the Hungarian town Kanizsa (now Nagykanizsa)
He attended the classic lyceum, and got the laurea (post-secondary academic degree) at the University of Padova in 1938, writing a thesis about eidetic memory. In 1947 he became a teaching assistant in the University of Florence. In 1953 he returned to Trieste with the role of full Professor at the University of Trieste, which he held for 30 years. He retired from academic life in 1988 and continued research until 1993, the year of his death.

I have read that cats bathe themselves after being handled by humans because they don't like our smell.  Maybe.  But my Cat bathes herself when she is laughing.  One day the dog, on a leash, lifted his leg to pee, she ran under him, causing him to fall over.  She ran to a spot just outside of leash range and took her bath.  Then ran under him again when he tried to pee, again falling over.  She took a bath.  Then as he tried a third time, she ran at him again, the dog, thinking he could out smart the cat, tried to catch the cat by scrunching down.  Didn't work because she jumped over him.  Took  a bath.  Another time she hid some of the dogs toys on top of the refrigerator and dropped them behind him, one by one.  Being a dog,  he couldn't figure out where they were coming from, and after each drop, she took a bath.  Many other instances of the cat pranking the dog, always took a bath laughing at him.  So I think the Scientists have it wrong, cats are just amused by us, and that is the real reason they stick around, for the laughter.
